Input.threadtitle: Why do we use a fixed learning rate?
Input.posts:
We're currently using a fixed learning rate alpha and then check how fast we find the solution for a given dataset with it. Wouldn't it be smarter to have a half-dynamic learning rate alpha instead? What I mean by that is: - start with a big alpha - for every iteration where we calculate theta: Check if we moved closer to the target theta. If we did not, reduce alpha for the next iteration (maybe alpha = alpha/2 ). That way we would need a lot less computational power, imho.

Input.threadtitle: Mean normalization when the features are not normally distributed - impact on gradient descent
Input.posts:
My question is, in short: Is it relevant that we normalize postive features in a not entirely fitting way? So far, we are not doing any statistical analysis with the data, so this issue is probably not a great one and might not have an immediate impact on the performance of gradient descent. However, with mean normalization we transform the feature into a random variable with the mean 0 and a standard deviation of 1, if I understand it correctly (give or take, if we take the range to normalize instead). This suggests comparison of the feature with a standard normally distributed random variable. However, as in the examples from the lecture (age, size, number of bedrooms), one can see that feature with positive values are not uncommon. But these aren't modeled by normal distributions very well. While normally distributed RVs allow very negative and very positive outliers with the same (small) probability. I cannot figure out why $$m\leq n$$ will lead to $$\begin{vmatrix} X^TX \end{vmatrix} = 0$$？

Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Why there are no local minima in Linear regression?
Input.posts:
I didn't understand the reason that there are no local minima in Linear regression problems. if there is someone who knows about this, please let me know about this question. Thank you.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
In order to see this, you might investigate the concept of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_function . If you design your cost function so that it is *guaranteed* to behave smoothly convex for all values (which some functions are), then local minima cannot occur.
